document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Rhithrogena Eaton, 1881 from the Far East of Russia with notes on this genus in this area (Ephemeroptera: Heptageniidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Rhithrogena Eaton, 1881 from the Far East of Russia with notes on this genus in this area (Ephemeroptera: Heptageniidae)

Sinitshenkova, 1982

(male imago, female imago and larva);

(synonym).

Female imago. Dimensions: length (mm): 6.0– 6.8 ; forewings 7.7–8.5 ; cerci 8.5 –11.0. Thorax: pronotum and mesonotum brown. All legs white with a dark spot in the middle of the femora. Abdomen: terga colored as in males, but with the pattern on terga expressed with greater contrast, a pair of small light spots and strokes does not merge and is easily visible on terga 2–7 . Sterna yellow-tinged grayish. Cerci white, uniformly colored.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 24–29.
Rhithrogena bajkovae
, male imago: 24. Mesonotum, dorsal. 25. Penis, ventral. 26. Penis, dorsal. 27. Penis lobes lateral. 28. Penis lobes, view from above. 29. Apex of penis lobes, dorsal. Scale (mm): 24=1.0; 25–29=0.2.

subSubSection.paragraph: Male subimago. Thorax: pronotum light brown; mesonotum white, shaded brownish. Legs white with a dark contrasting spot on the femora. Wings matte, translucent. Abdomen: terga white-tinged grayish, opaque; lateral portion brownish-grey. Sterna white. Cerci white.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 30–42.
Rhithrogena bajkovae
, larva: 30. Head, dorsal. 31. Labrum, dorsal. 32. Teeth of left mandible, dorsal. 33. Comb-shaped setae of the maxilla. 34. Gill I. 35. Gill III. 36. Gill IV. 37. Gill VII. 38. Setae on the dorsal surface of fore femora. 39. Abdominal sternum 9 (female). 40. Tarsal claw of fore leg. 41. Tarsal claw of middle leg. 42. Posterior margin of terga 5. Scale (mm): 30=0.1; 31=0.2; 32,40–41=0.01; 33,38,42=0.05; 34=1.0;35–37,39=0.5.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and biology.
Rhithrogena bajkovae
is an East Palaearctic species that is distributed in Transbaikalia (
Tshernova et al . 1986
), West Siberia (
Beketov & Kluge 2003
,
Beketov 2005
), Mongolia (
Braasch 1979
;
Enkhtaivan & Soldán 2009
) and the Russian Far East (
Sowa 1973
,
Bajkova 1979
,
Sinitshenkova 1982
,
Tiunova & Potikha 2005
, Tiunova 2008 , 2009) including Sakhalin Island (
Tiunova 2007 b
).

The larvae of this species were found in gravel and pebbles in small rivers or streams and in the middle part of large rivers, which can be characterized as types of rivers that are moderately cold and moderately warm.
